column14:
Human and veterinary as well as bacterial and viral specimens
and
It covers both human and veterinary medicine
column16:
Supporting both Human and Veterinary, are there potential conflicts inherent to supporting both that will need to be identified within resources, e.g. species?  From a practical implementation and certification process E.g.
1. We ran into a case where a medication code used in vetrinary medicine was used in human system certification testing, which was inappropriate and not supported.  Ultimately the Certification test data was changed. 
2. PDMP (Prescription drug monitoring program) data is not standard across states. In one state species was a  required data element related to a human patient denied a narcotic medication becasue it was also written for their pet. Species is also pointless data in a human based system. 

(also http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/overview-clinical.html )
Appears to be a link but is not

Consider your reading audience, Implementators need clinical support and its ultimately on them to find that. A first step to assist that, this documentation needs is to reduce the level of mental processing needed, there needs to be a terminology definitions reference specifically for Genomics.
Should this not be [1..1] and support null value if not available.
column25: It's not possible to send null values for missing elements.  1..1 should only be used when data elements are always expected to be present for all systems.

column16: From here http://hl7.org/fhir/uv/genomics-reporting/2019JAN/index.html There should be an indicator that the section is not ready. Either that or the location link is incorrect
Use Case suggested addition Under 3, Other. Consider a use case for Law Enforcement. This use case would also entail privacy / legal override considerations.
First paragraph seems to limit the scope to genetic reporting based on 'real' specimen. What about synthetic sequences?

The Overview includes signficant discussion of Variations, yet there is also a Variant Detection section that could have held much of this detail and have been referenced from the Overview. As it is today the Variant Detection section is under developed. So, either ballance out the two sections, or explain something new in Variant Detection section.
column17: Balance overview and variant detection sections

column14: In some cases, genotypes are sufficiently standardized to be conveyed as codes in genotype.valueCodeableConcept.code.
column16:
In which cases? Possibly is it in cases where some authority (system) has agreed to manage it as a code?
There seems to be too many hints here on when to use a codeableConcept.text vs a code; yet following examples seem to be clear distinction. So the lead text might simply need to be more assertive.
column17: More guidance on code vs. text

column14: From the diagram above, Genotype, Haplotype and Variant profiles will are used

column16:
Although this will work with some servers, the _profile query parameter is not a strong query parameter to use for selecting genomics information. It will also not work at all on servers that explicitly don't support the query parameter. It will give false-negatives on a server which was not given profile conformance values, or does not do automatic tagging.
This query parameter is also not very likely to reduce the returned results in any signficant way. 
I recommend against use of it due to these factors.

column16: In some places in the ballot it lists "shotgun" sequencing and other places it inserts a hyphen: "shot-gun" sequencing. Can you please clarify which one is correct?

column4: IG Home Page: Content and Organization- Cytogenomic Reporting
column14: Guidance on expressing information gathered by [[cytogenomic - link TBD]] testing techniques including FISH tests, chromosomal analysis, etc.
column16: Link is missing. Suggest you add link or delete where link is supposed to be.

column14: Medication Efficacy Impact describes how the associated genetic findings affect the effectiveness of the medication.
column16:
Can you please clarify? How do the genetic findings affect the effectiveness of medication? Wouldn't the findings either decrease or increase medication effectiveness?  Consider rewording for clarity. 
Also, is the valueCodeableConcept within this profile (StructureDefinition: Medication Efficacy Impact) correct? Here are the values listed: Resistant | Responsive | Presumed resistant | Presumed responsive | Unknown significance | Non-Responsive | Presumed non-responsive. Are these the measure of medication effectiveness or of the impact?
column17: How do the genetic findings affect the effectiveness of medication?

column16: The links in the header "Content and organization" shouldn't be buried and only found within this section.  They should be accessible from a tab within the main header and not just the Table of Contents.  Also, fix the numbering within each page to properly given unique numbers to each section of a page.
column17: Add additional tab in header to ease navigation to the relevant informational pages of the implementation guide

column14: Variations are detected by comparing a patients genetic sequence with a reference using a variety of techniques each with their own trade-offs in terms of applicability, cost, speed, availability, and precision. Some can only be used for DNA but not RNA or amino acid sequences or can only detect certain types of changes, for example.
column15: Variations are detected by comparing a patients genetic sequence with a reference using a variety of techniques. Each of these techniques come with their own trade-offs in terms of applicability, cost, speed, availability, and precision. For example, some techniques can only be used for DNA but not RNA or amino acid sequences. Others can only detect certain types of changes.
column17: Reword the last paragraph of the "Variant Detection" section within the Genomics Background page.

column16: There doesn't appear to be any description of how the figures should be read.  Yes, there is some information given about certain pieces of each figure, but the overall description of what is attempting to be conveyed by figure 1 is missing. For example, a paragraph stating that figure 1 shows a Genomics Report and the 5 possible observation types that can be recorded, how frequently they can occur in said report, and how these observations relate to each other (or whatever the intended meaning that is meant to be conveyed by the figure is) would be useful information to convey in text to avoid any confusion.
column17: Add more details about what the figure is attempting to describe.

column16: A table or more formal method of displaying the example data for each type of resource (?) in the Pharmacogenomic Example Instances section may make the information easier to interpret.  For example, maybe the use of a FHIR Structure table would make for a better display of the information you're trying to convey.
column17: Create a table of some kind to house the examples shown in the Pharmacogenomic Example Instances section.
